title: Worked Solution
text:
To express the given function \( h(x) $$=$$ \lvert $$x^2$$ + $$7$$ vert \) as a composition of two functions, such that \( h(x) $$=$$ f(g(x)) \), we need to identify two functions \( f(x) \) and \( g(x) \) where one function is applied inside the other.

Let's analyze the given options:

$$1$$. \( f(x) $$=$$ \lvert $$x$$ vert, g(x) $$=$$ $$x^2$$ + $$7$$ \): This choice correctly expresses \( h(x) \) because \( g(x) \) computes \( $$x^2$$ + $$7$$ \), and then \( f(g(x)) \) takes the absolute value of that result, which matches \( h(x) \).

$$2$$. \( f(x) $$=$$ $$x^2$$ + $$7$$, g(x) $$=$$ \lvert $$x$$ vert \): This choice does not correctly express \( h(x) \) because it would first take the absolute value of \( $$x$$ \) and then square it and add $$7$$, which doesn't require taking the absolute value after squaring and adding $$7$$ to \( $$x$$ \).

$$3$$. \( f(x) $$=$$ $$x^2$$, g(x) $$=$$ \lvert $$x$$ + $$7$$ vert \): This choice incorrectly represents \( h(x) \) because it implies the absolute operation is applied before squaring and adding $$7$$, which is not the structure of \( h(x) \).

$$4$$. \( f(x) $$=$$ \lvert $$x^2$$ vert, g(x) $$=$$ $$x$$ + $$7$$ \): This choice does not match \( h(x) \) because it suggests adding $$7$$ to \( $$x$$ \) before squaring, which is not what \( h(x) \) describes.

Based on this analysis, the correct answer is:

\( f(x) $$=$$ \lvert $$x$$ vert, g(x) $$=$$ $$x^2$$ + $$7$$ \)

This selection correctly composes \( h(x) \) as \( f(g(x)) \) by first performing the operation inside \( g(x) \), which is \( $$x^2$$ + $$7$$ \), and then applying the absolute value function \( f(x) \) to the result.
